metadata.title: Convert BTU to Joules – Energy Converter
metadata.description: Convert energy from BTU (British Thermal Units) to Joules (J), essential for HVAC systems, heating calculations, and international engineering applications.

introduction: This converter transforms energy measurements from BTU to Joules, enabling translation of HVAC specifications to SI standard units.
BTU is widely used in North America for heating and cooling systems, while Joules are the international scientific standard. This conversion bridges regional and global engineering practices.
This converter uses the precise relationship where 1 BTU equals approximately 1,055.06 Joules.
methodology: 1 BTU = 1,055.06 J. To convert BTU to joules, multiply by 1,055.06. For example, 1 BTU = 1,055.06 J, 10 BTU = 10,550.6 J.
HVAC systems specify cooling capacity in BTU per hour (BTU/h), but engineering calculations often require joules per second (watts). Converting enables proper equipment selection.
Air conditioning and heating units across North America use BTU ratings. Converting to joules allows international comparison and standardization.
This converter provides precise energy conversions for HVAC, heating systems, and international engineering applications.
examples: Example 1 – Air conditioning: A 10,000 BTU/h AC unit delivers approximately 10,550.6 J/s (watts), useful for power consumption analysis.
Example 2 – Heating capacity: A furnace with 100,000 BTU/h output produces 105,506 J/s, essential for home heating design.
Example 3 – Energy efficiency: A boiler using 50,000 BTU converts to 52,753 J of thermal energy, needed for efficiency calculations.

faqs.question: What is the conversion from BTU to Joules?
faqs.answer: 1 BTU ≈ 1,055.06 J. Multiply BTU by 1,055.06 to get joules.

faqs.question: Why convert BTU to Joules?
faqs.answer: Joules are the international SI standard. Most scientific calculations and international engineering standards use joules.

faqs.question: What is BTU/h in watts?
faqs.answer: 1 BTU/h = 0.293 watts. Dividing BTU by 3.412 gives the equivalent wattage for power ratings.

glossary.definition: Unit of heat energy, widely used in HVAC and heating systems in North America.
SI base unit of energy used in international scientific and engineering applications.
